title: Cindy Hyde-Smith
added: * [[List of American politicians who supported Donald Trump after attempted coup]]

title: Cindy Hyde-Smith
added: In January 2021, Hyde-Smith joined a group of Republican senators (led by [[Ted Cruz]]) attempting to overturn the results of the presidential election by announcing they would refuse to certify the votes of the Electoral College. Accordingly, on January 6, Hyde-Smith voted in support of the objection to Arizona's electoral votes. The Senate rejected this objection 93-6.

title: Cindy Hyde-Smith
added: On January 6-7, 2020, Senator Hyde-Smith voted to object to the certification of electoral college votes cast by Pennsylvania and Arizona in support of Joe Biden. She condemned the "unacceptable violence and destruction at the Capital" earlier that day, and continued, saying that her constituents "do not believe the presidential election was constitutional and cannot accept the Electoral College decision; therefore, I cannot in good conscience support certification."<ref>{{Cite web|last=Uhrmacher|first=Kevin|last2=|first2=|last3=|date=|title=How members of Congress voted on counting the electoral college vote|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2021/politics/congress-electoral-college-count-tracker/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2021-01-12|website=Washington Post|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Digital|first=WLBT|date=|title=Sen. Hyde-Smith joined 5 Senate Republicans in favor of rejecting Arizona’s electoral votes|url=https://www.wlbt.com/2021/01/06/sen-hyde-smith-joined-senate-republicans-favor-rejecting-arizonas-electoral-votes/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2021-01-12|website=WLBT|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Carter|first=Josh|date=|title=‘Remember them’: Hyde-Smith faces online scrutiny after opposing Electoral College vote|url=https://www.wlbt.com/2021/01/07/remember-them-hyde-smith-faces-online-scrutiny-after-opposing-electoral-college-vote/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2021-01-12|website=WLBT|language=en-US}}</ref>

title: Cindy Hyde-Smith
added: Hyde-Smith was participating in the [[2020 United States Electoral College count]] debate about the Arizona election when the [[2021 storming of the United States Capitol]] happened. Led by Senator [[Ted Cruz]], Hyde-Smith joined four other senators to vote to object to the certification of the Arizona 2020 presidential election results.<ref name="Baird">{{cite news |last1=Baird |first1=Addy |title=Republicans Are Still Trying To Overturn Trump’s Election Loss, Even After His Supporters Took Over The Capitol |url=https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/addybaird/congress-certify-biden-win-capitol-attack |work=BuzzFeed News |date=7 January 2021 |language=en}}</ref> Hyde-Smith was removed from the Senate floor to an undisclosed location, along with other senators, shortly after the Capitol was breached by the rioters. Her staff had to shelter in Hyde-Smith's office.<ref name="Beveridge">{{cite news |last1=Beveridge |first1=Lici |title=Mississippi lawmakers are safe, condemn violence at U.S. Capitol |url=https://www.clarionledger.com/story/news/politics/2021/01/06/mississippi-congressmen-respond-riots-u-s-capitol-building/6569336002/ |access-date=13 January 2021 |work=The Clarion-Ledger |date=6 January 2021}}</ref> During the attack, Hyde-Smith tweeted "Whatever frustrations any American may have, violence & destruction in the US Capitol, the seat of our democratic government, is unacceptable."<ref name="McCarthy">{{cite news |last1=McCarthy |first1=Caitlin |title=Strong reactions from Mid-South members of Congress to Trump supporters rioting at the U.S. Capitol |url=https://www.localmemphis.com/article/news/national/on-social-media-mid-south-member-of-congress-reacted-to-the-shocking-scene-at-the-nations-capital/522-1efb4fc5-70af-4e7c-8b00-869eb01ad213 |access-date=13 January 2021 |work=Local ABC 24 |date=6 January 2021}}</ref> She later said she was scared and called the rioters "criminals who need to be prosecuted."<ref name="Williams">{{cite news |last1=Williams |first1=Angela |title=Hyde-Smith calls mob that attacked U.S. Capitol ‘criminals’ |url=https://www.wapt.com/article/hyde-smith-calls-mob-that-attacked-us-capitol-criminals/35181194# |access-date=13 January 2021 |date=12 January 2021 |language=en}}</ref> After the Capitol was secure and Congress returned to session, Hyde-Smith also objected to the Pennsylvania Electoral College votes, as led by [[Josh Hawley]].<ref name="Ford">{{cite news |last1=Ford |first1=Craig |title=Lawmakers revealed positions on election challenge |url=https://www.wtva.com/content/news/Hyde-Smith-Guest-Kelly-revealed-where-they-stand-on-challenging-presidential-election-573544761.html |access-date=13 January 2021 |work=WTVA News |date=7 January 2021 |language=en}}</ref> Hyde-Smith based her decision on "the erosion of integrity of the electoral process." She also stated that her constituents "do not believe the presidential election was constitutional and cannot accept the Electoral College decision." Her decision was in contrast to fellow Mississippi senator [[Roger Wicker]], who supported certifying the election.<ref name="WLBT1721">{{cite news |title=Sen. Hyde-Smith joined 5 Senate Republicans in favor of rejecting Arizona’s electoral votes |url=https://www.wlbt.com/2021/01/06/sen-hyde-smith-joined-senate-republicans-favor-rejecting-arizonas-electoral-votes/ |access-date=13 January 2021 |work=WLBT |date=7 January 2021}}</ref>
